awd_titl_txt: Fostering Utah Education Learning for Grades 4-6 Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is expanding computer science into rural elementary schools in Utah by designing and testing a process for adaptation of existing computer science resources into elementary science classes in grades 4-6. It leverages a partnership between the Utah State Board of Education, Westminster College, and the Central Utah Educational Regional Service Center to addresses the question, “How can states and regional networks support rural districts in curating and adapting national resources for computer science education?” It is creating professional learning communities that bring together rural Utah elementary teachers with experienced science and computer science teachers, as well as educational technology trainers and national K-6 computer science teachers. The computer science units will be made available through CANVAS modules (the state licensed learning management system) as a way of making them accessible to other Utah rural teachers beyond the original cohort.

The research is investigating the process of adaptation of national computer science resources to rural K-12 needs, the rigor of the units created, and the success of implementation in the classroom. The team is using data on the challenges faced by teachers in those schools to iteratively refine targeted supports that include curriculum adaptations, differentiation of professional development (PD), and system-level supports that address the specific needs of rural school elementary teachers. To assess the usefulness of the adaptation, creation, and implementation process, the research involves interviews with both teachers and development team experts. Additionally, teachers are completing PD exit surveys and monthly implementation surveys. The team is also examining state data usage associated with the modules through the CANVAS platform as a way to measure implementation. The research is informing a model process for adaptation of national materials for computer science in rural K-12, and is being shared with the national computer science research community. This project is funded by the CS for All program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

por.por_cntn:
SRI is the evaluator of FUEL CS, a research practice partnership between the Utah State board of Education (USBE), Westminster College, and the Central Utah Educational Regional Service Center (CUES), that aims to increase computer science (CS) learning opportunities in rural Utah by designing and testing a process for adaptation and integration of existing CS resources into elementary science classes in grades 4-6. The project seeks to support rural teachers in adapting and using available lesson resources and developing lesson materials for broader use.

SRI?s evaluation (1) documents project activities and adaptations to the project plan based on evolving conditions, (2) describes the experiences of participating teachers and project leaders, and (3) contextualizes the findings within the broader CS education movement. The evaluation question is: What supports the adaptation of national CS resources and the implementation of the adapted CS resources in rural elementary classrooms?

The evaluation is based on data gathered through observations of professional development activities, notes from project meetings, interviews with teacher participants and project leaders, and observation of Advisory Board meetings. Throughout the project, SRI provided formative input to the FUEL team as well as technical assistance on instrument development.

Although impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic posed unforeseen challenges in both project years, the FUEL team responded with new strategies to support teachers and promote the integration of CS with elementary science lessons. The team developed a streamlined approach that focused on teachers? implementation of existing lessons (rather than creating new ones). In doing so,they learned important lessons about teacher and student learning in CS and strategies for supporting CS and science integration.

Key evaluation findings include:

  • Leaders and teachers recognize the value of hands-on learning and modeling lessons.
  • Teachers need more examples and support on the process of creating their own lessons.
  • There is a lack of alignment on the purpose, practices, and knowledge needed to integrate CS and science.
  • Teachers report positive student engagement in activities that integrate science and CS, but they are overwhelmed at the prospect of designing their own lessons without the support of the FUEL staff.

 The evaluation findings discussed above highlight the difficulty of translating professional development experiences into classroom implementation. Making this translation requires a strong shared vision, extensive opportunities for modeling and practice, and ongoing support from a community of practitioners. SRI shared the following recommendations with project leaders:

  • Continue using hands-on learning and modeling strategies during professional learning
  • Provide avenues for teacher community ? such as a forum, or Professional Learning Community (PLC).
  • Streamline and clarify the goal and vision of integration: is the goal to use CS lessons as culminating activities that reinforce science concepts? Or is the goal to integrate CS vocabulary and skills (e.g. loops, conditionals) into daily instruction?
  • Assign pre-work for summer PD that includes bringing pacing guides with units of study mapped out
  • Consider using CS lessons (e.g., a simulation) as a strategy for increasing teachers? comfort level with science standards AND CS standards simultaneously.

The project served elementary teachers from rural Utah elementary schools, and was able to develop strategies to support students engaging in computer science as part of their traditional science instruction. The opportunity to introduce computer science in schools that previously did not have a program was a broader impact of the program. 


Last Modified: 08/01/2023
Modified by: Sarah R Young
